Erik Neumann wrote:

> (I'm not testing how random the behavior is, I just want to
> throw a bunch of random possibilities at my code to get the
> code to break).

This strikes me as a very bad idea. If you get the code to break, how 
are you going to repeat it? And then how are you going to know if you've 
fixed the bug?

Much better to throw *every* possibility at the code, rather than just a 
random selection. You'd be surprised at the number of bugs this 
uncovers. I've discovered quite a few bugs in the JDK itself by 
exhaustively testing some things Sun never bothered to do more than 
sample testing on. I just found another one this morning. There are 32 
characters in the ISO-8859-7 encoding that Java 1.5 can't correctly 
encode. (This one's a regression. It worked in 1.4.)

If the problem space is so large that you really can't test every 
possibility, then write a program to generate random samples and *log* 
any that fail so you can add them to the test suite. That way you can 
run the few failing tests repeatedly until (and after) they've been 
fixed. However the actual generation of the random samples should be 
separated from your unit test suite.  Random generation of test data is 
antithetical to test driven development. Test driven development 
requires reproducible tests.
